description:
Chitinophaga eiseniae is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It was first isolated from the gut of the earthworm Eisenia fetida, also known as the red wiggler or compost worm.

Chitinophaga eiseniae is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. It is rod-shaped and capable of gliding motility. This species is known to be capable of degrading chitin, a structural polysaccharide found in the exoskeletons of many invertebrates, including earthworms.

The optimal growth temperature for Chitinophaga eiseniae is around 25-30Â°C, and it can tolerate a wide range of pH values, from 5.5 to 8.5. This versatility likely contributes to its ability to thrive in the diverse and dynamic environment of the earthworm gut.

Chitinophaga eiseniae is considered to be a beneficial microorganism, as it may play a role in the digestion and nutrient cycling within the earthworm's digestive system. Its chitin-degrading capabilities also suggest that it could have potential applications in the field of bioconversion and bioremediation.
